text: you know being out there and standing
here being close to the side like I am
right now it was very peaceful you know
it almost took you back to a time when
you know all the way back to when the
protesting started even I think being
out there marching you had a sense of
pride and I looked forward at my
children who were marching in front of
me and thought about when I may have
participated in peaceful marches so
proud that they were doing that and
thinking about when even my parents had
participated in things like that so it
was a moment of pride it was an exciting
moment that you felt good about standing
up just for a good cause coming together
for peace and for unity and then of
course the shooting began just tell me
how difficult has it been to navigate
your own emotions because you were there
at the March to voice your concern about
police behavior towards black people
then suddenly the police themselves
become victims you know that that was
really hard I think even right now it's
it's a little bit difficult for me to be
so close to the scene just recalling all
that happened right here remembering the
the moments of peace that that were
taking place in the beginning but I did
look back behind me and just to recall
how close I am to where we were shielded
and where we were protected and in those
moments you knew that the police
officers were there to protect us and
the federal officers that were there as
well that they were standing in the end
in the line of fire and true protection
and in true bravery now President Obama
has been in office two terms there are
critics that say there's not enough
progress that's been made on this issue
of race we heard in our piece we came to
before yourself a doctor there who
treated the police saying the problem is
a lack of an open discussion there in
America about race relations do you
share that that frustration it is not
being talked about that that is the true
and real frustration here I will say to
you that we attended a great community
conversation just last night my family
and I think that coming to the table
together is is where we have to begin if
we don't sit down and side by side and
try to listen to each other and look at
each other and really embrace each other
we can't begin the healing that that's
really where it has to start it has to
start with a conversation and any of us
understanding each other just briefly
because you briefly you told me you were
there at the March with your son you
have three children but what do you say
to your children about the police okay I
do I do tell them that they have to
respect authority but in the experience
that we had together out there I them to
respect authority I teach them to do
what the officers are asking you know
those are conversations unfortunately
right now that we do have to have but we
have to say respect Authority do what
they're asking you to do
keep your hands unfortunately keep your
hands up you know it's it's unfortunate
but I will tell you that in the wake of
this tragedy I awaken the next morning
and I told them that we
those officers they lost their lives for
us they were protecting us
